poem:
Lucy Powell Wins

In the silent hum,  
of ballots cast—  
a murmur of change,  
red-ribboned.

She, a whisperer  
of gathering storms,  
with softer resolve  
than the clangor of metal  
clinking aspirations.

Votes counted  
like rain on a still pond—  
a ripple,  
a moment.  
Not to outshine  
but to grow  
in earthen trust.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Lucy Powell wins Labour deputy leadership election Lucy Powell has won Labour’s deputy leadership election, beating her rival Bridget Phillipson, as she said the party would not win by trying to “out-Reform Reform”. Powell, who was the Commons leader until she was sacked in Keir Starmer’s reshuffle at the start of September, was seen as the favourite throughout the contest. She won 87,407 votes, 54% of those cast, while Phillipson received 73,536. Turnout of eligible". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
